element_texts.text:
4 pm The Marvellous
progress of the Country is well
exemplefied by this short
journey of 25 miles.
When I went to Ft Sulley
Sept /82 there was a 
little settlement of some four
or five houses in a valley
some four miles from  Pierre
just under a high hill
Today I stopped on that hill &
Counted in sight with the 
naked eye 101 farm houses
On a rise just south of 
Spring Creek I had stopped
& counted 96 farm houses.
All this in eight months of winter - 
Stopped at the Reed house in 
Pierre. & got as good room
as they have.

Pierre, Dak T   June 24th
The tramping around in the shell of a hotel woke me early. Got up & took breakfast about 5.30 AM Joe [?Saura?] & Ida saw me to the train  - soon after 6 am  I bade them good by - The rain had made every thing green  there was no dust & I had a very quiet but pleasant trip arriving at Lasota 11 pm - Had to room with an "Eastern Stranger" but the hotel is a fairly goodone. Got supper & went to bed at once -

reported a Genl Terry, &
found I had orders to go the
whole trip. Mrs. Bacon 
was sick  & B could not go.
A score in woman's favor-
Met Mrs. Rucker & was 
installed in a nice room of 
their nice house. Every
thing is very beautiful
inside & out.
Met many Offrs. strolled
down to post club in evening
when I got back found I had
missed several visitors
Went to bed about 11pm

 June 26th 1883-

Went to the Hd Qrs & spent 
the morning bugging the 
different heads of Depts on
behalf of my post -

June 27, 1883 - Directly after Breakfast Penrose (acs)  & I started to Town - Bought a lot of stores for the mess of our party also some thsings for myself. Made preliminary arrangements to get a cook & trailer  - but am not sure of taking them. Met my old classmate Sub Johnson, now a retired General. Bought everything the mess will want & am arranging to have it go on same train with us - Visited Genl. Terry & family in evening as soon as I could for

myself were standing to receivee him - there was great cordiality - handshaking for a few moments - & then as one of the ladies down the line remarked, the Circus was over. The visitors went to Bkfst, & we to our several houses. Drew my (?) from Pierre -- went to town - slowest place I ever saw, things promised last evening were not forthcoming. I actually waited until 4 pm for the stores I bought yesterday & for two hours more

then announced that he was tired out & in lieu of hand shaking would speak to them. He made one of his characteristic speeches, no eloquence but full of plain good sense Then Genl Terry was called for, & he rather botched it - for a lawyer he is a poor extempore speaker. Chf Justin Waite - in picture (unclear) Each made a few remarks which were well received - After all that fuss was over, on about

dinner by Genl Terry - I was half an hour late but had to obey of course slipped on my uniform coat & went over - [?] [?]  pleasant time Genl T. S. family delightful & cultivated people - Old Bach (brother & 4 Old Maid Sisters - touching - but seems a waste   Grand parade of Old soldiers just after dark Genl got tired of [?] speaking - so made them a speech - then Genl Terry Ch. Just Waite & Just. Grey were called out - Crowd very nice & well behaved

out all in splendid order except Genl S. who is a little sick - N.P. RR gave us passes & a splendid Pullman all to ourselves - & we make our start under the most favorable auspices - At Crow Wing ran out of the oak into the pine [?] & sandy soil - Hot as tophet & suffocating dust   Excellent eating car - Genl Terry & I played whist against the two Justices - & were shamefully beaten -
Terribly hot & very dusty
Took dinner & supper on eating car - both good

July 1
Tidball turned over to me $200 of the money in his hands contributed by the party - Still owe $134.91 - first view of snow-clad peaks - Diminishing river & narrowing valley.
Judges Waite & Grey went on to Helena  Lost our car at Boseman but were permitted to ride in the car of the Officers of Road - Snow mountains all around - rivers very high. fear we are too early in the season - Very heavy grade in Bozeman's pass

Fort Ellis  July 2nd
Got sub'ce stores for trip - also mess furniture -  Hired another Chinese as waiter - Ordered stove, grid-iron & lunch box - all to order - spent several hours in Bozeman - a very flourishing place - Started our Mess with an excellent dinner by our "Chinese" -

 3rd Repetition of above - very busy - Vice Presdt Edmunds & a Lt of Navy joined or agreed to join our party - Gen'l Terry

Had a really excellent dinner & we all enjoyed it very much -  Had tressle bedsteads made for the party but the General "scorns them with big heels" - He is the only man I ever saw who takes a positive delight in discomfort - He was watching the Cavy Compy get off yesterday.  a wagon was being loaded with comfortable rolls of bedding when he turned to me "Why Dodge look at that - Every private soldier has as much as a Major Genl ought to have"

Making it very slippery & the travelling was simply wretched  - The wagons could not keep up & we had to stop frequently to wait for them.  At a ranche on Frail Creek we waited until nearly 4 pm - the "Old Man" was reluctantly forced into Camp about one mile below the ranche at 4.15 pm - Tried fishing but failed to get a bite - Creek too high & muddy - pretty camp 5500 feet above tide water & 17 miles from Fort Ellis.  Cleared off in afternoon though clouds still hanging around -

where there was good fishing but he went into camp about 2.30 pm on this creek - where there is no fishing & poor grass - several of the party tried fishing in river but got nothing.  I tried & lost an excellent double leader & three fine flies - I also lost today my old Conroy reel which I valued very highly
Mammoth Springs   July 7th  83
Made a good start this am.  The road is up a sharp canon of the Yellowstone &

went to work - Genl Sherman & the wagons go from here direct to the lower geyser basin while all the rest of us take horse & pack mule train for the falls & Canon -  Was very busy seperating the eatibles &c - Genl will Mess with Capt Gregg while we take Lieut Erwin - [?] Hotel
Baronett's Bridge  Jul 8th
Got under weigh about 9 am  The trail or road is for wagons but rough & very steep.  Camped near the Bridge about 4 pm after a long & hard mardh  The bridge is historic - Joseph

to look at Tower falls over which the creek plunges into the river chasm - Coming up the mountain on south side the Chief Justice saddle slipped back, his horse began to kick it was a bad steep place & the Chf. was thrown or fell off & badly hurt - Fortunately there happened to be a party of tourists camped very near among whom was a Dr. - He said that one & possibly two of Judge Waites ribs were cracked.  He put on a bandage - the Judge remounted & pluckily came on - changing horses with Hughes -
At Tower Creek we commenced the ascent of Mt Washburn

Mud Geysers  July 10th 83
The party got off about 7- am  The Chf Justice Tidball & myself remained to do again all the points of interest -  The view of Falls & Canon from point Lookout is indescribably grand & beautiful - Fish hawks nest - Chf Justice feeling much better, but very sore -  At upper falls we joined a good wagon road - along the banks of the Yellowstone here very placid & beautiful flowing through lovely meadows & full of huge trout rising languidly - I could not stand it Tidball had a short line

Alum Creek  July 11th  1883
Started late & marched only 10 miles - during the last two days we have scarcely ever been out of sight of a smoking boiling spring - passed many today & camped about 2 miles from a group which Senator Edmunds & I visited - Found every body out fishing when I got to camp so took my rod & went to work - Killed 16 very pretty little fellows 6 to 8 inches long - Chf Justice Waite had a very bad time today.  We are only about 10 miles from Genl Sherman & the Com'd so Genl Terry

about an hour took 24 - Tried fishing in a beautiful lake (Neary's) on the divide but there appear to be no fish in it - Arrived at Genl S's camp on East fork of Madison about noon - No fishing - bagged 4 young ducks which were very excellent.  Tisball & I were lying in our tent when who should ride up but McCook - He of course met with a most cordial reception.  He is with a party on a flying visit.  Dr & Mrs Curtis of N.Y (Mrs C is Mc's sister) [?] Daughter & a [?] Philips a friend of the Chf. Justice.   Dr Curtis at

McCooks party got off before we were  up - We got off at 7 am about 9 reached Lower Geyser Basin & found the General waiting for us looking rugged & well & glad to see us - Here we all bade good by to the old Chief Justice who almost shed tears over the parting & all of us were touched - He was so genial so kind so winning took everything so well - was so manly under all the novelty of camp life & bore his hurt & pain with such plucky fortitude that he had endeared himself to every one of us - He is the exact contrast to Judge Grey who

Sprigs & Geysers.  We camped at 12 m - within 200 yds of Old Faithful which spouts regularly every 65 minutes - From my tent door when I sit I can see the steam arising from 30 or 40 geysers & springs   Almost the whole valley is occupied by them & their deposits.  The Giantess went off three days ago & her periods are 2 weeks.  We will not likely see any of the very grandest - that is those which throw very great volumes of water - We have seen the "Grand," the "Castle" the "Bear:. but Old Faithful is the reliable & beautiful - Sat up late chinning with Arthur

Lower Geyser Basin  Head of Madison Rivr   July 15, 1883
Broke camp at 8.30 am  Tedball & I left camp much earlier so as to give a parting visit to the wonders - Arrived at the Hotel at Lower Geyser (Marshall's House) we found the Genl & Chf Justice - Terry had determined to go in & as soon as they could get their dinner the whole party set out.  Genl Terry * Hughes - Chf Justice Waite Senator Edmunds & Lt Arthur. Capt Gregg & Lt Erwin - Only four of us left Genl Sherman, Judge Grey, Tedball & myself

Tarhee pass   July 16, 1883
The very middle day of summer, yet we found the thermometer at 22º when we got up - or 10º below freezing with ice in our buckets & wash basins    Got off about 6 am McCook ahead.  The road is a very heavy grade rising about 1800 feet in about 6 miles - then came to a tremendous drop down (a road made by Howard when in pursuit

Potter Creek   July 17 1883

 Got off at 6 am - rode in ambulance with Genl - wont do it again if I can help it - for he has a miserable narrow wagon - very uncomfortable in every way -

Passed Henry Lake early & escaped mosquitoes but had six or eight miles of miserable roads - Stopped for half hour on Snake river (Henry's Fork) & saw a young Moose & the skin of the mother

Beaver Cañon   July 18, 1883
Rode out on horseback ahead of party which did not catch me until I had gone 6 miles.  Saw several sage hens & took two shots at a big old Cock but didn't get him.  Saw a young Curlew - Road over long uninteresting flats - sacred to the Mesquite & horse fly - Reached Utah Northern RR at 12 M & followed it for 4 miles to Beaver City & camped - Passed yesterday & today immense herds of cattle being driven from Oregon

Willow Creek near Spring Hill   July 19th 1883
Took horse & rode ahead  Delightful morning but the McCook Champaign left only unpleasant effects.  Rather sick at stomach for some hours - Got into Camp about 12 M.  Went fishing & worked hard for 3 hours with very poor results  3 trout & 2 white fish - Had a good nap - The road has been uninteresting   The mountains on either side being obscured by a mist -

Head of Big Hole   July 21, 1883
Got off a little late, 6.30 - In eleven miles reached Bannock City - a played out town of about 100 inhabitants.   Once the proud capital of Montana with 10,000 inhabitants - Old mines in every direction - a few are yet worked, but yield but little - stopped an hour - bought lots of things - pushed on up Grasshopper Creek & by a long but not difficult pass crossed divide to Big Hole   Bagged 4 young sage hens - Judge a [?] as a shot - Took about 20 nice trout after getting in camp - cold -

Camp on Trail Creek  23d July
Left camp on horseback half an hour ahead of party   Took a musket & had [?] of an antelope   got a 400 yd shot at one running - & another about same distance at one standing overshot him by 2 inches   Road very crooked - passed Gibbons battle ground about 11 am, crossed pioneer Ck & turned up Trail Creek - Rode it on horseback - [?] camped near top of mountain - flies  no fish - 5 grouse

[?] I had kept on my horse though it was very hot - Road through canon as bad as possible to be passable - The very hardest days march we have made both on men & animals tho' only about 26 miles  Beautiful camp on bank of Bitter root - Nine Trout none over half a pound - 5 Grouse - elegant little fellows - Judge took 3 trout

This valley is destined to be a very rich community - soil good only needing water & there are numerous irrigating ditches - Camped at Mitchels   He took us into his farm on river - put us in a beautiful camp   Took 7 very fine trout  Judge took 4 little ones

  Very hot in sun but a fine day.  with beautiful scenery -

Gen'l rec'd his [?] & we drove up to Hd Qrs to shake hands with Comd Off & tell him that we were going into Camp - All hands invited to dine with Maj Jordan & all accepted except [?] who went off to dine with Thompson - The Offs of 3d apparently very glad to see me - Disappointed in Ft Missoula  It is not nearly so [?] a post as Sully & I think badly arranged - (Genl Sherman says he planned it so I dont say this out loud}

On Cars from Missoula   July 27 - 83 -
Up at 4 am - got all our things seperated - sent back matrasses &c but brought our necessary outfit   Left Fort M. at 7 am, Got all my baggage cared for then we loafed about town until 9 am.  when the train started - [?] Offs down to see us off & found Baldwin on board in charge of Morse & some [?Judiciary?] just retrd from Washington

Fort coeur d'Alane  July 28, 83
All our party had a magnificent breakfast at Wheatons - post & surroundings lovely beyond compare - This is certainly God's Country - & I would gladly compromise on it for my Heaven - Got a cook - temporary - My bed lost off Wagon last night - worried - found by Mail carrier on road & brought in - wrote letters all day - Concert to Genl at night, & a nice time with the ladies - Put out washing -

Coeur d'Alene  July 30 - 83 -
Lovely, lovely, lovely.  Fishing in late afternoon with Jackson who rowed the boat - 41 beauties in 3 hours - one 2 pounder Rainbow Trout - a fish peculiar to the River outlet of the lake -
July 31 -
Mills & party arrived   Went up lake on steamboat - French on board - took five trout - Dr Wood rowing me not much but all that were taken by 3 so called skilful fishermen - a       So called lunch at Rowly which in

Ladies - & bade good by to all - They are exceptionally charming & I have lost a heart to not less than half a dozen of them - Packed up & finished of all business  As I went to my tent I heard the pleasant sounds of a musicale - but I was not to be tempted - Had a siege of it in getting packed as I always do when I stop for a day or two - 
Spokane Falls Aug 2 -
Up very early, & got breakfast  Wagons reported 4.30 am

but we got off soon aftr 7 am - all the Offs being down to see us start - I dont think I ever left a post with so much regret - Travelled by a very good road to Spokane Falls - arrived 1 pm - dined at Hotel - Lovely camp fine falls - Thriving town.  Genl W. recd the people at night in Cannon Hall & I was tired & bugged off -  Mr. Cutter was very polite wanted me to fish - also to visit his charming wife who I met at the ball at fort  Begged off all

Chamokane Ck  Aug 4 -
Started 7 - slow road - hot & dusty - Tried fishing at Spokane Bridge no go - only two little ones  Came on to Haring Ranche got forage & yet came on 7 miles to a good camp on this creek except that the grass is very poor - But having got oats at Harings dont care - Judge tried to take com'd but I did not see it - He has been very good - a few little fish

is very fine & noted in the Terry - In many places it is 3 ranches wide a perfect land almost all under fence - & in grain & grass - Oats & Wheat both poor -  Arrived at Browns 11.30 & ten minutes later the Genl came in in Judge Grey's ambulance - both mad - the Genl because I had not camped last night at Hayny -- the Judge because he was crowded in ambulance

Fort Colville  Aug 6. 83
Broke camp 6.45.  Road fairly good, except around base of rocky mountains - great slopes of loose rocks 500 ft high giving a feeling of insecurity as we wind through the narrow path at their foot -  The river is a fraud disseminating itself in great Tula ponds & Lakes & getting smaller as we go down - We were too slow for Miles who passed us entirely

Opposite old [?] Fort Colville   Aug 7 - 1883
Broke camp 6.30 am - Our road led back to the new town of Colville - where we stopped for half an hour - I bought a good quantity of vegetables   About 9 am arrived at the mission of St Frances Regm - The Indian agent was at the post gate & asked us to go in - The Genl consented with great reluctance as he hates to stop en route - But we had a surprise - The children were dressed up in grand style & welcomed us with songs & speeches & finally a character

Camp in Woods - Aug 8 - 1883
Broke camp 7 pm - with all our things on pack mules   In the hope of getting some game I started ahead with Mr Saurin & Lieut Rowell & two orderlies - Willis a geologist of the NPRR & his assistant were with us - we crossed Kettle River & rode gaily forward killing some ducks that is I killed 2 mallards   Our destination was a forage pile hid somewhere up Dead Mans Creek - said by the Engineers to be 7 miles up it - We found the marks of a large Camp about one mile up - looked everywhere for the forage but finding none went on -

On Settle Mountain Trail   Aug 9, 1883
Up with the earliest dawn & pushed forward to overtake Abercrombie - Caught him by 5 am, yet in bed & all asleep - Got a good breakfast & then loafed round for all day - Last night was not unpleasant - I made a bed of pine boughs & wrapped myself in my saddle blanket with saddle for pillow - Rourke constituted himself cook & gave us an excellent supper of ducks & grouse, cooked on a tin plate without salt bread or coffee - The only serious advantage was the abundance -

[?Huasket?] River   Aug 10th 1883
Broke camp at 6. am   Had a delightful canter ahead with Genl Miles who was equally with myself bound to get some game - fish - I got 9 grouse & about 20 trout but all small - Miles beat me in weight tho he got only 8 or 10 & a Lt Bachus beat us both badly getting 17 fish that would go altogether up to some 8 or 10 lbs - one over a pound - It was very hot & I was tired out fighting my beast of a horse who insists on keeping his nose in the

Myers Creek   Aug 11th 83 -
Broke camp 8. am to give a working party time to cut out a bad piece of fallen timber in front of us - Had a delightful ride - over a beautiful country.  Came over the very highest mountain  of our whole trip - that is the highest rise in a short time - about 1500 feet in 2 or 3 miles - No accident or incident - 6 grouse - no fishing - the working party killed many grouse with carbines  Wagons waiting on here to take Genl S. to Osoyoos - but he [?wont?]

Similkameen River   Aug 13.  1883
Got off about 7 am. which was good considering that all the pack trains had to be reorganized - four miles above the American, we came to the Brittish Custom House - The Collector Judge Haynes came out to meet us, & invited us all into his house which is by far the most pretentious on this frontier - Gave us a variety of drinks though I confined myself to the Irish whiskey.  When the pack trains were all up we packed on - Osoyoos Lake narrows - a man named Koenger has built a bridge accross the narrow place

Similkameen River  Aug 14 . 1883 -
Broke camp 5.30 am  Ten miles brought us to Price's Mill - ten more to a pretty good camp on the banks of the river - No game  Beautiful scenery, but the air is so filled with smoke that little can be seen -
Similkameen River  Aug 15, 83
Broke camp at usual hour  Six miles brought us to some very pretty fields & a village of Indians - They live in houses, wear civilized clothing & are Brs. [?] subjects - with all the

Old Powder Camp   Aug 16, 1883
The Genl disgusted because he is ahead of programme - He is very curious in many respects - this a.m. he would not start until 6. though for the first time on the trip all was ready by 5.30 - Five miles brought us to Allison a ranch occupied by a man wife & ten 10 children - the oldest 14 - the nearest white neighbor is 40 miles away - They can raise no vegetables & have a stock ranche with some 200 head of cattle & some horses - the first five miles of the trail very bad - Genl determined to go back to

Foot of Hope Mountain    Aug 17, 1883
Started at usual hour 6 am & made the summit of the pass in 3 hours - This is where we 4 picked to camp tonight & the Genl did not like to go on especially as there was good grass - Finally however he decided to take the cañon trail (there being two) & to camp at the head of Canon - Before 12 m. the guide stopped & informed the Genl that we had arrived at the place -

Lake House   Aug 18, 1883 
Waked rather late to find the whole camp buried in snow - not less than 2 inches deep cold raw & disagreeable & still snowing We got under weigh at 6.30 & such a journey?   The trail was as bad as bad can be, barely passible in places, muddy, boggy - very slippery, with rocks enough to make it dangerous - Sometimes on horseback sometimes on foot sometimes going up hill sometimes down

I have [?] seen Mountains [?] very steep - 1500 to 2000 feet Avalanches & Water Spouts have torn these throwing great masses into the Valley, blocking out the stream for miles - One Waterspout very recent - the [?] to be [?] in these mountains - At 1.30 struck the old wagon road built years ago by Her Majestys Royal Engineering   It was a good road & cost a deal of money & labor but is now

Fort Hope  Aug 19
Broke camp 8 am in order to give the animals time to feed.  We are out of grain & the grass is very poor.  The march today was very beautiful through a deep canon - the sides scored by avalanches & waterspouts - The trail is an old wagon road built at enormous expense by Her Majesty's Royal Engineers in 1861 - part of the work of the Boundary Commission.  It is in remarkably good order considering that it has never had any repairs but some of the bridges have been carried off &

Steamer Western Slope  Aug  20th 1883
Up early - struck camp & soon after 5 am got on board steamer where I found all our party -  Steamer stopped an hour to take on 97 head of cattle -  River very swift - stopped quite frequently at one place took on 1 ½  tons of cheese - stopped for an hour at a Salmon cannery owned by a man named Adair - Inspected establishment - very interesting - New Westminister was passed about 5 pm. beautiful little place at about 10 pm stopped at a landing 10 miles from

At 10 am the Genl visited the Governor - At 12 m. we all went aboard the Red Cutter Wolcott - Capt Moore - & steamed for Squimault the Great Brittish Pacific Naval Station - There we went aboard the great Iron Clad the Swiftsure - There were three other large men of war in the Harbor - all under Comd of Admiral Lyons - a Cousin of Lord Lyons - We were handsomely entertained shown through the vessel & had an exhibition drill - at 4 pm we returned to our vessel steamed for Port Townshend - where we arrived

About 4.30 pm returned to the Walcott & steamed for Tacoma arriving about 8 pm  There was not a bed to be had for love or money so we ret'd to the Walcott where the Capt had made beds on the floor of his cabin.  We went to bed & were very comfortable -

Fort Vancouver  Aug 23d
Got breakfast at Hotel - bade good by to our hospitable entertainers on the Walcott & took car for Kalama & then took boat for Vancouver where we arrived 4 pm  Were met on the dock by Genl Miles Morrow, Green & all hands - Went with

Genl S. dined with Greene & me had the native terrapin cooked by Lt Wood 21st Infy - all pronounce it a marked success.  & to me it was just as good as the Maryland article -      [?Mills?] gave a grand reception at night 7 all had to attend - It was a complete success - Met Mrs. Clarke 25th Infy -  Did not feel very well & did not dare to dance with one as I would have had to dance with several  - Tried to make myself agreeable  but gave it up as a bad job - went home about 11.30 with Greene leaving the female family to return with the son-in-law  Bonesteel

with about 5000 people - Tidball & I cut the whole thing - After it was over Mills Morrow Greene a lot of the other off. came to the Hotel after us & taking us to Eppengins saloon came near piping us out with quantities of lush - Fortunately they had to leave to catch 12 pm boat - & we got to bed tho worse for wear but not helpless.
Portland Oregon On Bd. Steamer Oregon    Aug 26. Sunday -
up late with a big head & disordered stomach   Got a good Breakfast then went to Steamer Oregon to

took refuge on Steamer Oregon which is to sail as soon as she can see her way.  Genl & Judge came on about 11.30  to bed 12 m
Steamer Oregon  Aug 27 1883 -
Was waked up by a heavy surge & scrape to find ourselves aground - It was only 5 am & I went to sleep again.  When we got up to breakfast the ship was still aground but we were only 3 miles from Portland & the Capt had gone for assistance - Our ship had her nose buried 11 feet in the sand & mud of the bank & was aground amidships -  By 9 am there were three powerful boats tugging at

Steamer Oregon   Aug 28, 1883
When I waked this am the steamer was already under weigh & as it was a bright beautiful morning I got up to see the famed Bar - at mouth of Columbia    Water smooth as glass & we passed the ordeal as pleasantly as if sailing over a Millpond - the Capt says he never saw the bar so smooth - After we got to sea, the ordinary rolling of the vessel affected me unpleasantly - & I began to feel white about the gills  Took a little drink then a light breakfast there

talked & [?] - was [?] 5 pm when I finished off with a huge Dinner seafaring is most excellent for eating & sleeping  three square meals since daylight  & at least 14  hours of sweet sleep since yesterday - so far have had a most delightful voyage - The Engineer has just told me that he hoped to sight the Pointe Arena light in half an hour & if so we will sleep tonight in Frisco - I write this 8.30 pm -
